message.content:
We first extract the necessary values from the three statements.

1. Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio  
  • From the cash flow statement, the “Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities” is –1,368,775.90.  
  • From the income statement, “Net Profit” is 1,167,783.63.  
  • The ratio is calculated as:  
    Ratio = (Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities) / (Net Profit)  
      = –1,368,775.90 / 1,167,783.63 ≈ –1.17  

2. Current Assets Turnover Ratio  
  • “Total Revenue” from the income statement is 3,397,619.40.  
  • Total current assets are given on the balance sheet at the beginning (8,000,000.00) and at the ending date (9,891,156.92).  
  • Compute average current assets:  
    Average = (8,000,000.00 + 9,891,156.92) / 2  
      = 17,891,156.92 / 2  
      ≈ 8,945,578.46  
  • The turnover ratio is:  
    Ratio = (Total Revenue) / (Average Current Assets)  
      = 3,397,619.40 / 8,945,578.46 ≈ 0.38  

3. Quick Ratio  
  • Quick assets generally are defined as: Cash on Hand + Bank Deposits + Interest Receivable + Accounts Receivable. Using the ending amounts:  
    Cash on Hand = 2,339,224.10  
    Bank Deposits = 4,292,000.00  
    Interest Receivable = 14,796.43  
    Accounts Receivable = 2,902,136.39  
    Sum of Quick Assets = 2,339,224.10 + 4,292,000.00 + 14,796.43 + 2,902,136.39  
      = 9,548,156.92  
  • Total Current Liabilities is 631,880.98.  
  • Quick Ratio = (Quick Assets) / (Total Current Liabilities)  
    = 9,548,156.92 / 631,880.98 ≈ 15.12  

Thus, our final solution is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio": "-1.17",
    "Current Assets Turnover Ratio": "0.38",
    "Quick Ratio": "15.12"
  }
}
